rows.text: Correspondence with the Palestine Arab Delegation and the Zionist Organization
Jews right to immigrate but must not exceed "the economic capacity of the country at the time to absorb new arrivals."
Jewish national home: "a center in which the Jewish people as a whole may take, on grounds of religion and race, an interest and a pride."
No benches or screens could be brought to the Western Wall by Jews, since they had not been allowed during Ottoman rule.
Statement to the Permanent Mandates Commission
Palestine, Statement with regard to British Policy
government must issue clear statements safeguarding Arab rights and regulating Jewish immigration and land purchase
welcomed an investigation by an international commission of the conflicting claims to the Western Wall
Statement of Policy by His Majesty's Government in the United Kingdom Presented by the Secretary of State for the Colonies to Parliament by Command of His Majesty. (Passfield)
Obligations "of equal weight" to both communities
Stricter controls to be placed on Jewish immigration and land purchase
Renew the effort to establish the legislative council proposed in 1922
Statement of Policy on the Peel Commission report
Statement of Policy, appointment of the Woodhead Commission
Statement of Policy on the Woodhead Commission's report
Statement of Policy presented by the Secretary of State for the Colonies . . . (MacDonald)
No partition, with creation of self-governing institutions and shared authority over 10 years
Limited Jewish immigration to 75,000 over five years; subsequent immigration would require Arab approval. Purchase of land would be limited in some parts of Palestine and forbidden in others
